blog.name: 54daysormore
blog.title: 54 Days or More
blog.description: BTS Fan Fiction ... Masterlist ... Personal Account ... Twitter ... Instagram

title: What Remains
body:
Summary:  Being unable to smell wouldn’t matter if you were anyone else in a completely different world.  For you, it means you don’t–can’t–won’t ever find your soulmate.  So is it any wonder that you don’t believe the guy who one day insists you smell like jasmine?  

A/N:  I’M ALIVE!  After three weeks of crazy work, gross depression, and being sick, I finally got to write some.

HOWEVER, there were a lot of intimate scenes I wanted in this chapter, and I found that I just couldn’t write those well or quickly, ugh.  So, while this is THIRTY-FIVE pages, it’s still not what I was expecting.  Oh well.  Also not super proof-read, so may edit it later, but you’ve all waited so patiently, so I wanted to get something out! Enjoy!

It’s the wedding chapter!  Please see ending notes for more info.

I am aware that this gif is NOT a peony, sad day.

The italics in this story are Y/N’s thoughts or past dialogue.

Warnings: Some bad words. Underage drinking (Don’t do that!  It’s overrated!)

W/C: 16,613 (!)

Masterlist

15. Dogwoods

16. Peonies

“It starts between two suns
Between dream and sleep
Like a sigh after oblivion
-The way you hold the night.

It goes on in a kiss
So many pains exchanged
Like a song of compassion
-The way you reveal my name…”—Emmanuelle Soni-Dessaigne

          Hoseok loved weddings.  Loved.  Hoseok loved love.  How could he not like weddings, then?  Plus, dancing?  Alcohol? Hot men in suits looking hot? What’s not to like?

          Hoseok hated anxiety, though, and found loving people who had hate in their hearts hard to do.  It’s a testament to the nurture argument in psychology that Jungkook has turned out so differently than his parents.  Hoseok has never really disliked people as much as he has disliked Jungkook’s parents lately, and if the way Jimin’s face was screwed up was any indication, then the other man must be feeling the same.

          He had merely come to check in on Tae, and consequently, Jimin, since Jungkook had insisted he was ready and it was time to start, so he almost closed the door immediately when he saw two other figures in the room, but if Hoseok was a cat, he would have been dead a long time ago, because his curiosity has always gotten the best of him.  Jungkook’s parents aren’t ugly people—he clearly got his good looks from somewhere—but they were ugly people.  Desperation, surely, or pride, must have gotten the best of their senses at some point.  Something had to explain why they seemed to care so little about their son.  Hoseok knew it wasn’t quite his place or business to stay in the room or make himself known or listen at all, but something about what Mr. Jeon murmured about

          “I can’t believe we’re letting him marry a man,” made him stay.  Because he knew that there were people out there in the world who still didn’t agree with men marrying mem or women marrying women despite that fact that soulmates often were of the same sex.  He knew shelters around the city and probably the world were filled with kids whose parents didn’t agree with them being with their soulmate purely because they were the same sex, but still, it jarred him to hear.  He only entered the room to shut the door so Jungkook wouldn’t have to hear the rest.

          “You’re letting him marry his soulmate,” Tae said besides his own soulmate, a fierce and intense look in his eyes Hoseok rarely saw. He was glad he rarely saw it, honestly. An angry Tae, just like an angry Jimin, or maybe an angry anyone, scared Hoseok a little.

          “You’re not even letting him do that,” Jimin said, wrapping his arm around Tae for support.  “I had to pay you before you even allowed that.  Now, as I know we didn’t invite you, I’m going to have to ask you to leave, as there can’t be any reason for you to be here unless you want something else, and you’re not going to get it, whatever it is.”  Jungkook’s mother had the audacity to try to look affronted at the idea.

          “I am just here to see my boy get married.”

          “He doesn’t want you here,” Jimin said.  “And I don’t either.  It’s his day, our day, and you no longer have a right to take part of it.”

          “What will it look like?” Mr. Jeon said, stepping toward Jimin.  “What will it look like if his parents aren’t there?”

          “It will look like what it is,” Tae almost sneered. “Like you aren’t wanted.”

          “My parents aren’t here either.  They also lost the right to have any part in my life when they refused to accept who the world had provided for me and I had managed to find and be found by.  So, unless you have a question about the payment I already sent you, or the paperwork we have already filled out, you need to leave.”  If Hoseok wasn’t so hopelessly in love with Tae, and his best friend wasn’t about to marry him, Hoseok might have had to claim Jimin for himself.  He seemed to be burning with a passion that terrified and enthralled Hoseok.

          Jungkook’s parents seemed to think, or seethe, for a moment, perhaps looking for an iota of an excuse to stay.  Hoseok hoped, deep down, that it was some buried deep love for their son that they wanted to stay, but the way that they finally scoffed and stormed out, barely giving him a glance on the way, crushed those ideas quickly. Their exit brought Hoseok to Jimin and Tae’s attention, and they let go of each other so Tae could come to him, enveloping the man in a tight hug.

          “Hey,” Jimin said, buttoning his blazer.  “Is Jungkook okay?”

          “Oh, yeah,” Hoseok said over Tae’s shoulder. “He asked me to let you know he’s ready.”

          “Don’t, uh, tell him, yeah?” Jimin said, still fidgeting with his suit.  “I don’t want—”

          “I have no idea what you’re talking about,” Hoseok said, winking and smiling widely.  “I saw nothing.  I heard nothing.  In fact, am I even here?  Are any of us here?”

          “Stop,” Tae mumbled, nipping at his ear before pulling away, an arm still held tightly around his waist.

          “Seriously, though, you handled it well.  I don’t know what I would have done if they came to Jungkook’s room.”

          “Shit,” Jimin said, the idea having seemed to have not occurred to him as he rushed for the door.  Hoseok made sure to stop him before he got too far, though, putting his arm out to pull him into a hug that Tae quickly made into a group one.

          “Hey, whoa, he’s alright.  Y/N’s in there, and I told her not to let anyone in except me. You know it’s bad luck to see the groom before the wedding.”

          “Well then,” Jimin sighed even as a relaxed smile spread over his face, “we’re doomed considering I saw him an hour ago.”

          “Yeah, no, you’re so gross nothing could doom this marriage,” Tae said, and Jimin simply blinked and looked at his arm around Hoseok’s waist.  His soulmate didn’t seem deterred, though, as he pulled Hoseok closer.  Hoseok sometimes wondered if the two soulmates did speak telepathically, because Jimin laughed as Tae rested his head on Hoseok’s shoulder. He felt a little out of the loop, if he had to be honest, but he knew they weren’t being malicious or even meaning to.

          “Go do your best men duties,” Jimin said, waving them out.  “I need to finish getting ready.”

          “Wait, we actually have to do stuff?” Tae pouted as Hoseok tickled his side so he would stand up straight. A mere wave of Jimin’s hand sent them off again, and as soon as his back was turned Hoseok leaned over to give Tae a peck on the cheek which made the man smile as he straightened his own clothes before nodding.  “Ready?”

          “Ready,” Hoseok nodded back, even if he wasn’t exactly sure that was 100% true because he wasn’t 100% sure what Tae meant by the question.  Still, he followed him out.  He would be a dutiful best man.  He’d do anything to ensure Jungkook had a perfect day.

          Nothing was perfect in life, of course, even on the day of a wedding between two souls who were clearly meant to be.

          “Oh my god, fucking, I can’t, it just, why won’t it button?” Jungkook whined and huffed, his fingers dropping lamely to his side. You tried desperately to resist an urge to laugh at him.

          “Hey,” you said as you closed the door behind you, since something needed to come out of your mouth and you assumed laughing at the boy in his nervous state wouldn’t help anything.  “Let me.”  He thankfully did, staring up at the ceiling and sighing as you easily buttoned his blazer. Smoothing out his collar and adjusting his bow-tie even though it didn’t need to be, you patted him on the shoulder and stepped back, giving him a final look-over.  He spread his hands open in front of himself as if to be on display, and you nodded approvingly.  He still only sighed again and slumped into a chair before shooting back up immediately, smoothing out his coat and fussing with his pockets.  “You look extremely uncomfortable.”

          “You think?” he huffed, fiddling with his cuffs.

          “Are you nervous?”

          “Only a ton.”

          “Why?”  The question was simple, but Jungkook still looked up at you seriously as if constructing an argumentative thesis in his head before he responded.  “I mean,” you said slowly, “he is your soulmate.”

          “Yeah, no, it’s not that.  It’s.  It’s,” he sighed, looking past you at the door again.  “I just really don’t want to mess up.”

          “Oh,” you said, fighting a smile again.  “Well, while I try to make it a point to not quote him, my dad once told me that some nerves are good.  It just shows you care.”  Jungkook looked suspicious, so you only shrugged.  “I mean, if you didn’t care, you would be apathetic.  You obviously want to do well and make Jimin happy, so you’re nervous.  Not that you should be.  You’ll be fine.  Great, even. It’s just a ceremony.  What really matters comes before and after, right?”

          “Right,” Jungkook said, but he still looked uncomfortable or anxious.  You couldn’t imagine why, as his confidence always seemed boosted around Jimin lately. You saw him anxious at the coffee shop, but that was different.  That was trying to please twenty different people at once who were nigh impossible to please even on their best days.  He could make the perfect drink, which he always did, and they could still get upset. They weren’t really upset at him, but he always seemed to take it that way.  It was understandable, even if sad.  You didn’t like seeing Jungkook at work, so out of control and uncomfortable.  You didn’t like him looking so anxious now, either, but you really didn’t think he should be.

          “What, um, exactly do you think you’re going to mess up?  Hoseok and Tae have the rings, right?”  A nod. “You know your vows.”  A statement, not a question, because you knew he did, but he still nodded.  “Is it Tae? Are you worried about if it will be weird or something?”

          “No, no.  Not much is going to change.  I mean, some stuff, but not much.”

          “Okay.  So, what are you worried about messing up?”

          “Just.  You know how sometimes you meet someone who’s better at you at something you want to be good at?”

          “Only like every day,” you mumbled, only half-joking. Jungkook glared a little before he continued, not meeting your gaze.

          “Jimin is just good.  I know he is.  He has a lot of experience.  And I…” Jungkook trailed off, leaving you blinking and struggling to be patient and understanding when you would much prefer him to just be blunt.

          “At what?”

          “You know.”

          “I really don’t.”

          “You know,” Jungkook said forcefully and slowly. You were about to insist, again, that you didn’t know what he was talking about, when he raised his hands, made a circle with one, and proceeded to stick his pointer finger through it.

          “Oh my god,” you screamed, doubling over in laughter, much to Jungkook’s chagrin.  “Oh, oh my god.”  Struggling to stop laughing, you reached for a nearby chair to stable yourself, almost wishing like you didn’t know what he was referring to.

          “Stop,” Jungkook grumbled.  “I’m serious.  What if. I don’t know.  I suck?”

          “Oh my god,” you said, almost falling over again at his word choice.  He seemed to realize it belatedly, too, as he huffed and his cheeks started to color a little.  “Isn’t—wouldn’t—wouldn’t that be good?” you said between breaths.  

          “Where’s Hoseok?  Isn’t it time to go?” Jungkook mumbled, pushing past you to open the door.  You recovered enough to stop him even though your eyes were still watering, leaning against the door to catch your breath and keeping him from escaping.

          “Hold—hold on,” you said, putting out your hands to stop him and steady yourself on his shoulders.  “I’m—I’m sorry for laughing.  Jungkook, I’m just, it’s just, oh wow, you don’t have to worry about that. I mean, I get it, but really, Jimin’s experience, as you call it, will only serve to help.  I’m sure he’ll take good care of you.  Just, I mean, as a non-male, I don’t think I have much advice for you—”

          “I don’t want your advice,” Jungkook said, looking appalled.

          “But at some level it’s all the same.  You don’t have to be in love to have sex, but I’m sure it helps.  Just don’t expect it to be perfect the first time, yeah?  It’ll probably be awkward and weird and—”

          “Great pep talk,” Jungkook said, trying to get past you again.  He easily could, you both knew, if it was purely up to strength, so he must not have actually wanted to leave the room, just the conversation as he let you stop him.

          “I’m just saying, he’ll be good to you.  And that will make it great.  Just be good back.  You’ll have to tell him what you like and don’t like.  You know him.  He’ll insist on knowing, maybe even to an annoying point.”

          “Yeah, yeah.”

          “But that means you actually have to tell him,” you said, poking his chest again.  “And be honest.  It’ll be good.  Like you said, he’s good.  Probably good at it, too, but good more so.”

          “Okay,” Jungkook groaned.

          “Don’t worry.  It’ll be good.”

          “Is it good with Yoongi?” Jungkook said so casually and yet quickly that you withdrew your finger back just as fast.  The way he blinked and then started to smile down at you was a sign for you to withdraw before he got the upper hand.  He knew that the question alone was already an Ace card, and you turned to open the door, trying to push him back so he couldn’t see or get out.  

          “I’ll go get Hoseok, I’m sure he has a lot of great sex advice,” you said as loudly back at Jungkook as you could, shutting the door in his face before he could stop you.  The door clicked loudly behind you and radiated through the quiet, but not empty, hallway.  The silence only lasted for a second when you saw Hoseok and Tae standing across the hall, smirking at you, Hoseok’s eyebrows raised.  “No, I do not want to explain,” you said, waving your hands in front of your face to get rid of any unwanted questions or comments.  “And I don’t want to explain.  I’m going to go sit down now.”  With the shared laughter of Hoseok and Tae fading behind you, you fled down the hallway to the small sanctuary, trying to slip into your seat unnoticed.

          You mostly were, but the pianist’s fingers misstepped, and a note went missing or a note was added, something barely jarring in the flow of music but enough for you to know that someone did notice you entering, and you ducked your head, trying to not be a distraction.  The music continued flawlessly, but you still knew he was watching.  You found yourself, as the song continued, unable and unwilling to not look up, though, something drawing your head up.  So it was no surprise to see Min Yoongi staring and smiling back at you from the stage, his fingers moving effortlessly over the keys as he didn’t even look at them. It seemed like he had been waiting for you to merely look up, because the second you did and your eyes met across the room, his smile melted into contentment before he focused all of his attention back on the piano in front of him.  If you had anything else to focus on, you would have, but you didn’t.  Completely shamelessly, then, you simply watched Yoongi as you sat and waited for the ceremony to begin.  

          Frankly, you watched him even after the ceremony began. You had seen him that morning but had to rush out to help Kimie finish decorating and help Tae and Jimin get things ready.  Yoongi had arrived in the past hour and let you know via text.  As people filed in, mostly just Jimin’s dance friends and a handful of people you didn’t know, some indescribable anxiety started to settle in as the people began to, as well.  It wasn’t like Jungkook’s nerves.  You had nothing to be nervous about, after all.  You weren’t getting married, and nothing was expected of you the rest of the evening since the flowers were done and you were just going to go home and sleep next to Yoongi like you had been doing for a while now.  Something about watching everyone sit down, leaning into someone’s ear next to them to whisper something about how pretty it was or about how the famous Min Yoongi was playing beautiful piano music, made you keep looking at Yoongi and the empty spot beside you, though, and by the time Yoongi paused, looking over at you one last time before he started the wedding march, you realized what was wrong, even if it made you feel a little pathetic.

          Weddings had always left an odd taste in your mouth. You had only been to a few that you could remember, but even one could have been enough.  Seeing people so in love and so meant for each other—each one you had gone to had been one between soulmates—had left you numb and hopeless, possibly border lining on angry.  While weddings brought two people together and thus their families and friends, uniting strangers and solidifying a relationship between many people for years to come, they always had made you feel even more alone.  Looking up at Yoongi now, even if you knew you were his soulmate, made your skin itch and your feet bounce up and down in anticipation. You throat felt parched, and your heart beat too quickly and yet seemed to sink.  Curling your fingers together until your nails dug into your palms, you told yourself to calm down.  You were and therefore would be happy for Jimin and Jungkook and not frown and pout and be upset that Yoongi wasn’t sitting beside you.  It was just for a few hours.  Afterwards, you could go home and be as close as you wanted to him.

          So why did you still feel like you were going to be alone forever?

          The ceremony, thankfully, was short, and you were able to concrete on Jimin and Jungkook.  They made it hard not to.  Tae and Hoseok stood alone on the stage near the priest—the same one commissioned to marry off Jungkook before—something about Jimin having “a ton of friends, but I don’t, so no, only best men, no groomsmen.  Your side would be embarrassingly huge.”  They seemed unable to take their eyes off of each other, too, though it was Hoseok who was eyeing Tae more.  He looked at his friend entering with Jimin, but only barely, before his eyes went back to Tae’s.  His smile seemed to widen any time the man seemed to catch his gaze and shoot him a smile.  They both looked sickenly happy and in love, so much so it might have looked to some that they were getting married.

          The peonies you and Kimie had picked for the wedding contrasted nicely with Jimin and Jungkook’s mostly white suits, and you thought it appropriate and sweet that they walked each other down the aisle, having no time or place for their fathers or mothers to do the honor.  The priest spoke not of anyone giving someone away, but of giving each other to the other.  Of meeting halfway and yet always taking things all the way.  Of never leaving anything unfinished or unsaid. Of completing each other by being complete.  It was overly sweet and befitting of the two who couldn’t stop smiling at each other, even if Jungkook’s face was almost the color of the flowers he held.  You kept stealing looks at Yoongi as the priest talked, relieved to see him smiling back at you, but you did look back at Jungkook when he handed Jimin the small bouquet he had walked in with.  The action had been completely his idea.  He hadn’t cared at all, and Jimin had had no preference, about what type of flowers you and Kimie thought would look best.

          “That’s why it’s your job, not mine.”  But, naturally curious, he had asked why you picked peonies for them, and you had touched the soft petals in front of you that you had brought to show them as you explained.

          “I knew peonies were your flower the moment I met you.  They can symbolize bashfulness.  But,” you had said before Jungkook could contradict you, “they can also mean compassion. If that isn’t Jimin, I don’t know what is.  In addition, they stand for prosperity, specifically in marriage.  I picked it for you but then for Jimin and then for both of you.  It also can stand for someone bringing honor to their entire family through success, and you will.  You already have.  Jimin will be your family, and he will be yours, and you will be nothing but successful.” 

          It was that, apparently, that made Jungkook think of passing or sharing the flower with Jimin, not only as a symbol of himself, but also to represent him giving himself and all his bashfulness to him.  You couldn’t tease him for that, even if Hoseok had, and you smiled to see Jimin receiving the flowers from Jungkook with his own smile even as they exchanged their vows. It was strange, in a way.  Weddings are full of such small, seemingly meaningless or mundane actions and words, and yet said at that moment, done in that space, shared in front of your friends and family, they become lifechanging and binding. The words Jimin and Jungkook spoke to each other were nothing new, even if they did put their own twist on the traditional vows shared between soulmates.  Even this change was nothing new, as a deviation from the norm was to be expected from the two.  But it seemed like the whole room held its breath as the two spoke.

          “You’re mine.”

          “And you are mine.”

           “Now and always.”

           “No matter what the world says.”

           “Until the world ends.”

           “Or my soul stops.”

           You barely remembered to breathe even when they finished and kissed, a soft, chaste kiss that almost made Jungkook look bashful again, though that was probably due to Hoseok whistling like a frat boy at a keg stand behind him, because Yoongi was staring at you from across the room, certainly not kissing you, and you felt incomplete and wrong, so much so that you stood up.  But Yoongi turned back to the piano, and everyone else was standing up, too, as Jimin and Jungkook marched proudly back down the aisle. You remembered to smile, because it was easy to, almost impossible not to as your friends passed you.  How could you not smile at such happiness?  And you remembered to look back at Yoongi one last time before following the crowd back out, smiling at the way he was watching you leave.  Because, really, how could you not smile at that?

           Being involved with the decorating had its advantages, as you had had a say in who you got to sit next to.  You picked Kimie and her husband Kai, obviously, and Minghao and Jun.  The rest of Jimin’s dance crew and Seth sat nearby.  An empty seat reserved for Yoongi was by you, too, though you doubted he would join the table for much of the evening.  He seemed to have teleported to the room and was already set up at a small table with a studio’s worth of sound equipment.  It looked much to over the top for a small wedding, but it was fun to see him work. While you saw him plenty of times at home concentrating hard on his work, seeing him public was something new. He was just as dedicated and passionate, perhaps even more so, and every time you felt some weird sort of jealousy—could you be jealous of music?—it dissipated quickly only to be replaced with some weird sort of pride—could you proud of Yoongi? It’s not like you had any part in what he was doing.  Still, it was hard to distract yourself from him or with him.  You knew speaking to the people at your table would be polite, but you just wanted to watch Yoongi.  You also knew you should just go and talk to him if you wanted to, but you didn’t want to distract him from his work.  You also wanted to concentrate on Jungkook and Jimin sitting next to Hoseok and Tae at the front of the room.  There was just a little too much to concentrate on or to try not to concentrate on, and you eyed the alcohol table wistfully, wanting something to help slow you down and dull your senses.  

          You resisted for a long time, thankfully, and were distracted by food and your tablemates.  Kimie and Kai had plenty to say about Bomi and all of her antics, and Minghao and Jun had plenty to complain about from the company.  They questioned you repetitively about why you hadn’t been to the show yet, and you promised them over and over again that you would. Kimie, the busybody that she was, kept trying to get you to talk about Yoongi, but her husband thankfully kept her in check, clearly more aware than she was, or more caring, about how often you were glancing at Yoongi across the room.  You stopped by your friends’ table, too, but you didn’t want to stay long.  You saw them often, and you didn’t want to hog their time.  Plus, Hoseok looked about ready to bring up the conversation you wanted to avoid that Jungkook had been embarrassed about, and you weren’t about to dive into that mess. So you caught up with Seth and chatted about the shelter and met the rest of the guests with no expectation of remembering their names come tomorrow.

          But by the time the dancing started, some fancy and rich but small meal nestled in your belly, the lights dimmed and your desire to pout and wallow in self-pity returned.  As your tablemates got up in pairs to go dance, you merely sat and watched and sipped on the glass of wine that had somehow made it to your table and into your hands. It wasn’t that you wanted to dance. You really didn’t know how to, certainly not like Jimin and Jungkook and, well, everyone else, seemed to know how to.  Dancing like everyone was doing was not so much about doing certain steps or even doing them correctly, but it was about being close.  This type of dancing, of leaning close and resting a cheek on someone else’s shoulder, was about intimacy, about trust and a desire to simply belong to another person.  This type of dancing made your insides burn.  Or maybe that was the glass you finished and refilled to avoid watching how content everyone looked on the dance floor.

          Still, you turned back in toward the table and glowered a bit, an urge to pretend to text someone coming over you.  You could go on a quest for the bathroom or find something else to distract you with, but you knew nothing was going to be enough. The scraping of a chair nearby barely even caught your attention, though someone’s hand refilling your glass was enough for you to look up.

          “Having a blast?” Seth said casually with only a hint of sarcasm in his voice.  Unsure how to answer, you kept your mouth shut, and he put the bottle down slowly until you turned enough to look at him.  “Do you want to dance?” he said once you were, but you wrinkled your lips and brow in answer.  “Yeah, me either.  Just thought I’d ask, though, as you looked pretty bored.”

          “Not bored,” you hummed, “just not much of a wedding person.”

          “Me either,” Seth said, “but this one seems nice.”

          “Yeah, it turned out really pretty.”

          “You look really pretty, too,” he said, and you laughed, waving a hand at him before sipping on your drink again.  

          “Yoongi picked it out.  I’m pretty clueless when it comes to being fancy.  I feel pretty out of place.”

          “You look it.”

          “You don’t look much better.”

          “I don’t disagree,” Seth shrugged.  It’s not that he didn’t look nice.  He cleaned up well, but he clearly was someone unused to wearing tight, fitted, pressed shirts and ties practically strangling his neck.  You wondered if his sense of discomfort was anything akin to yours.

          “You, uh, didn’t bring a date?” you said, not sure how to simply ask outright if it wasn’t just his clothes that made him feel out of place.  The idea made Seth laugh, though he didn’t look upset or annoyed.

          “Nah, no time for that right now.  Hey, can I ask,” he said, scooting his chair closer and leaning in a bit, “how it’s going with Yoongi?”

          “Huh?” you said eloquently, not sure if you were surprised by the question or his proximity or by how long it had been since you had looked over at the man in question or by how much you apparently had had to drink.

          “Yoongi.   How’s it going with him?  I only ask because I thought, when you left before Thanksgiving to go stay with him that you weren’t too happy about it.  You seemed really sad to leave, but then you didn’t come back.  So I just wondered.  I mean, I assume it’s going well.”

          “Oh,” you said, sighing for some reason and sinking back into your chair, your posture surely not eloquent or attractive. “Yeah.  It’s going well.”

          “What’s it been like?  I mean, I’m taking this class on documented soulmate oddities. It’s so fascinating, and I told my professor about you.  She was, is, super interested.  So I just wondered what it’s been like without being able to smell and all.”

          “Seth,” you said slowly as it seemed like he was getting riled up.  He rarely did, except on book club nights, and even then it was in pure ridiculousness. “I’d prefer if you didn’t talk to other people about me.”

          “Oh, right.  I mean, I didn’t say your name.  Purely from an academic standpoint, it’s an interesting case—”

          “I’m not a case study,” you frowned, sitting up straight and putting your glass down, suddenly needing your head to be clear. “Or an experiment.  My experience isn’t something to be documented or analyzed like some lab rat.”

          “No, of course not,” Seth backtracked, leaning closer on his knees.  “But don’t you think you should tell your story?  What if there are other people out there like you?”

          “There aren’t.”

          “You don’t know that.  Look, Tae’s whole point in starting the shelter was to help people with soulmate oddities.  The world doesn’t accept them.  I just want to help.  I couldn’t even believe I found this class to begin with.  Some university in Sweden has been studying oddities—”

          “I don’t like that word.”

          “Sorry.  Unusual? No, because there is no usual, not really.  Well, there is what society expects, and then there are people who don’t meet those expectations.  And that’s not a bad thing,” Seth emphasized.  “Society should change its expectations, is my point.  Society shouldn’t look down on you or treat you differently or anything.  But one way to help them stop doing that is to normalize the differences.  Everyone thinks things are a certain way because they’ve been told that, they’ve read that.  If we tell them different stories, write down different stories, then maybe they’ll stop being so, I don’t know, ignorant and awful.”

          “I agree,” you said slowly, because of course you did.  “But, my story, if you will, isn’t over yet, so I don’t think it’s time to share it yet.”

          “Fair enough,” Seth said, finally leaning back and looking around the table for someone’s drink to steal.  “But let me know if you ever want to, yeah?  I mean, scientifically or psychologically, or whatever, it’s fascinating.  But I also just care about you, you know?  So I just want to make sure you’re happy with him and not feeling coerced.”

          “Coerced?” you said, frowning as Seth nodded.

          “Yeah, lied to.  Manipulated.  I mean, he could be lying to you.”  Despite your past thoughts and actions and words, you felt yourself bristle.

          “I thought about that.  I thought that, honestly, for a while, but I know now that he isn’t.”

          “How do you know?” Seth said, not trying to trick you or be mean, just genuine curiosity and care in his tone.  “I mean, if no one else can smell you and you can’t smell him.  How do you know?”  Reaching for a glass of water, you thought for a moment before answering, looking out at the crowd.

          “Have you met your soulmate yet?”

          “No.”

          “Do you think you will one day?”

          “I hope so.  I could live without her, or him, but I know I would be glad to meet them.”

          “Could you see yourself dating or being with someone even if they weren’t your soulmate?”

          “Totally, I’m not opposed to much,” Seth shrugged, and you thoroughly believed him.

          “At some point, they might tell you they loved you, right?”

          “I hope so,” Seth laughed softly, and you nodded, agreeing with his reaction.

          “So how would you know, if they weren’t your soulmate, that they loved you?”

          “Well, I would just trust them.  Maybe know by how they acted, too.”

          “Well, that’s it then,” you shrugged, smiling softly back at him.  “That’s how I know Yoongi is telling the truth.”

          “Fair enough,” Seth smiled back, lifting his—or whoever’s it was—glass as a form of salute toward you.  “Then I am satisfied.”

          “Glad I could help,” you said, laughing as you finished your glass of water.  The two of you sat in quiet for a bit before he excused himself, saying something about wanting to check on Tae, and soon Jun and Minghao slumped back into their seats, panting hard and fumbling to get water into their glasses without making a mess. The dance floor had become crowded as the music shied away from only slow-dancing, and the men were already sweaty, loosening their ties and leaving their blazers on the back of seats instead of clinging to their backs.

          “You know, for dancers, I would think you would have more stamina.”

          “Oh, no,” Jun panted, “the opposite.  We dance so much, even a little bit more is like running five extra miles.”

          “Stop exaggerating,” Minghao laughed, slapping his partner on the back as Jun gulped down water.  “We’re just exhausted from all of the training plus shows.  No shame in being tired.  We still look better than most of those fools out there.”

          “Ming!” Jun gasped, smacking him in return, but Minghao just laughed, pointing at Ten and Taemin currently trying to out body roll each other next to Kai and Kimie who both looked unperturbed.  Realizing he was just talking about their ridiculous friends, Jun joined in in laughing at them, especially when Tae and Hoseok joined in, entrapping unsuspecting and innocent bystanders just trying to have a little harmless fun and exposing them to their shameless sensual twists and turns. Having someone sitting with you at the table calmed your nerves a little, though part of you was still itching to move or leave or do something.  When Jun got up, mumbling something about finding more water, you sat next to Minghao as he smiled and hummed while watching his friends.

          “Hey, Minghao, could I ask you a question?” you finally said, eyeing the way Jimin and Jungkook were dancing slowly and closely, more rocking and whispering into each other’s ears, despite the upbeat tempo and grinding of bodies all around them.

          “Of course.”

          “You know Yoongi?  The guy DJing over there?”

          “Yeah, of course I know Min Yoongi,” he laughed, not even needing to look.

          “I was wondering—well, there’s this girl at the shelter who can smell everyone’s soulmate scent.”

          “Oh, wow,” Minghao breathed, his smile fading. “Wait, like me?”

          “Not quite.  Tae explained it like she smells everyone’s, so she thinks everyone is her soulmate.”

          “Oh, wow,” Minghao said again, his eyes going impossibly wide.  “Shit. Fuck.  That’s.  Wow, that must be awful.”

          “I don’t know,” you shrugged.  “I mean, I imagine so.  Not exactly easy to deal with.  I just thought, maybe some day, if you have time, after the show and everything, that you could talk to her?  You’re the only person I know who could probably relate to her at all.”

          “Oh, yeah, wow, I’d love to,” the man said, clapping his hands over his thighs, some bubble of excitement over the prospect growing within him.  “Wow, poor girl.  Yes, please tell her I will.”

          “I will,” you smiled.  “But I was also wondering, well, she said Yoongi smelled like Christmas, and I—”

          “No,” Minghao said, his smile fading and his face instantly serious.

          “What?”

          “No,” he said again as you frowned.

          “I didn’t even ask anything.”

          “I know what you’re going to ask.  Everyone asks.  But I’m not going to tell you what he smells like.  The last time I did that”—his gaze searched the room until it fell on Jungkook and Jimin—“I almost ruined something good for one of my dear friends, so no.”

          “But you didn’t,” you persisted.  “You helped.  You helped make this day happen, in fact.”

          “The answer is still no.”

          “But—” you said, sounding desperate.

          “Isn’t knowing he smells like Christmas enough?”

          “What?  No,” you huffed, crossing your arms over your chest.  “Couldn’t that be a thousand different smells?”

          “Why does it matter to you, anyway?  You can’t smell him,” Minghao said.  He shut his lips the second it was out of them, but it was already too late.  They opened again immediately as he surged forward.  “Shit, I’m sorry, I didn’t mean—”

          “You did.  And you’re right.  It’s okay. Forget I asked, or, almost asked,” you said, standing up.

          “Y/N, seriously, I shouldn’t have said that, I’m sorry, I just don’t—”

          “I get it,” you sighed, even if you didn’t really.  If you couldn’t smell him, why was it such a big deal to just confirm or deny what someone else said he smelled like?  But Minghao was right.  It shouldn’t matter to you what Yoongi smelled like, since you couldn’t smell him, anyway.  But to be reminded so quickly and bluntly when you were already feeling a little untethered and insecure did nothing to help your insecurities.  Standing up only made it all worse, as the world seemed to spin a bit as you fought to steady yourself, reaching out for nothing until your own two feet started to move toward something.  You weren’t sure, and yet you knew exactly where they were heading, and you all but tripped or fell, wishing you weren’t so tipsy and clumsy, into Yoongi’s arms not even halfway to where you had last seen him, hiding behind some computer screen and adjusting the sound as everyone else danced the night away.

          “Hey,” he said into your hair, his arms already wrapping around you, steadying you and guiding you all at the same time.  “Let’s get some air.”

          You didn’t really want or need any air unless it was what he was sharing with you, so you followed him, no, walked with him, outside.

          “The music,” you mumbled half-heartedly, but he only chuckled and pulled you closer, amazing you at his ability to not trip or let you trip even though not one of your four legs combined were walking in a straight line out the doors.

          “I set up a list.  I’m not even needed.”

          “That’s not true,” you sighed into his chest, feeling like he must surely be carrying you or you were both floating because you were moving still despite how much you were clinging to him.  “I need you.”  He merely hummed in reply, but it went straight through your hair and into your scalp and sent goosebumps all over your skin, though that may have simply been the winter air.  “Cold,” you gasped as you suddenly realized you didn’t have a coat on.

          “Yeah, I didn’t think this through,” Yoongi laughed, hugging you tighter.  The warmth radiating off of his chest did help, but your legs and arms were chilled exponentially.  As he fumbled to open the door to get back inside, you couldn’t help but laugh into his chest, the whole scene warming you even more, though not as much as when you finally did get back inside, both of you breathing and shuddering in relief at how warm it was inside.  Still, he didn’t lead you back into the room where everyone was.  You could hear the music, still, even if some words sounded slurred and the bass was louder than anything else.  There was no need to hold onto Yoongi anymore, but you still did.

          “Are you having a good time?” he said softly, and if he meant at that moment, you knew the answer was a resounding yes, but you shifted a little to look up at him.

          “Honestly?” you said, waiting for him to nod.  “Yes.  Everything seemed to go smoothly, and Jimin and Jungkook look so happy, and everything is beautiful.”

          “But?” Yoongi said for you, hearing it already in your voice.

          “It’s selfish,” you said, hiding your face back in his chest.  He let you for a moment, perhaps thinking you would tell him without any prompting, but you swayed back and forth enough times for him to finally nudge your shoulder. “It’s stupid.  It doesn’t matter now,” you muttered.

          “I see,” he said, his tone clearly not convinced. “Well, I’m having a great time, too, if you want to know.”  Realizing how rude you were being, how truly selfish you were, you lifted your head up to apologize, but Yoongi was only smiling.  “But I realize I would have preferred sitting with you.”

          “Oh.  Oh?”

          “Oh is right,” Yoongi chuckled, his thumbs barely moving up and down in tiny motions on your back.  “That’s never happened before.  And I’m not complaining.  I didn’t think about it, when I told Jungkook I’d help.  I just thought, hey, music, I can do that.  I want to do that.  I love doing that.  I didn’t think about how hard it would be to not be able to be by you, to whisper about how good the place looked or about how happy the boys seem.  I don’t really care for big social events, so I didn’t think it would matter, not sitting by you at dinner and refilling your glass and making sure you had everything you needed.  I didn’t know a wedding would make me so sappy, but it’s been really hard to concentrate all day, because I just want to take care of you, and seeing you sitting alone was a sight I loathe, absolutely hate.  You should never, ever be alone unless you want to be, you know?  Like, if you need space or something.  But otherwise, I should always be right beside you.” Yoongi slowed down as you looked up at him, your mouth slightly opened.  You thought, for a moment, that he must be suddenly reading your mind and revealing everything that you had been feeling for hours, which was, of course, absurd, but still.  “Is that pathetic?” he said with a crooked smile, causing you to shake your head adamantly.

          “No!  No.”

          “Then you’re not, either,” he said softly.

          “How did—”

          “I could say something about being your soulmate and thus being able to read your mind or something,” Yoongi almost chuckled, “but I don’t even know if it’s as deep as that.  You just—you’ve gotten easy to read, is all, so I could tell.  And, besides, no one likes to be alone, much less on a wedding.  Being single at a wedding is the absolute worse.  Trust me, I know.  I wanted to die at Namjoon and Jin’s.”

          “Yoongi, you shouldn’t joke about that.”

          “Right.  No, I know, sorry.  But, I mean, it makes you feel incredibly lonely and depressed.  Or it makes me feel that way.  And I was standing over there, pushing buttons on a computer thinking how it didn’t have to be that way.  You were literally right across the room from me.  Will you be mad if I was kind of waiting to see if you could come up to me first?”

          “You were busy working!” you scoffed, hitting his arm lightly.  “I was waiting for you to notice how unhappy I was and come make it all better.  What are we, twelve?  Isn’t that sad?”

          “If it is, then we’re just pathetic with each other,” Yoongi laughed.

          “For each other, yeah,” you said teasingly, but Yoongi went a little stiff, and you looked up again at him to see him staring at you seriously.  “What?”

          “Do you mean that?”

          “What?” you repeated, looking around uneasily.

          “Do you really mean you’re pathetic for me?”

          “Yoongi,” you whined, not liking how teasing his voice was becoming.

          “Do you want to slow dance under the moonlight with me?”  His hands moved to your hips as he started to sway back and forth, bringing your body with him easily for a moment.

          “Yoongi,” you tried to complain, but instead you just put your arms over his shoulders, feeling even more like a twelve-year-old at some middle school dance with no experience and no idea of how to handle the flurry of bugs threatening to erupt out of you like some flesh-eating alien.

          “Do you want to cuddle and watch stupid movies just as an excuse to be close to me?” he said, pulling you closer with a hand on your back so abruptly that you almost squeaked in surprise when your hips collided.  He simply looked down at you for a moment as he continued to move his feet in tiny patterns as you followed him effortlessly and wordlessly.  This wasn’t dancing, it was simply being, and even though you could still feel the cold from the door nearby, you felt yourself warming up as a comfortable heat crept up your neck.

          “Do you want to kiss me,” he breathed, even as he did so, the mere side of his lips touching your skin so faintly that you almost wanted to turn your head just to feel the rest of them, “until we’re both breathless and desperate for more?”

          “Y-Yoongi.”  You almost gasped, like the pathetic, totally-gone-for-Yoongi person you were, your fingers slipping to his collar purely to have something to hold onto.  Nothing he was doing was new.  You were used to him rubbing his cheek against yours.  You were used to him whispering things into your ear that may have embarrassed you at one point but now only made you feel safe and wanted and longing for more.  You were used to the kisses on your neck or behind your ear or along your collarbone that always stayed in the same area but sent a shock through your entire body. But you were used to Yoongi always initiating and acting.  You never reciprocated, and something twisted in your gut akin to regret and guilt, like you had messed up and had been hurting him by never giving back to him. You weren’t used to acting upon what you wanted or asking for what you wanted or simply taking what you wanted, either, so you were more surprised than Yoongi was when you pushed back against his cheek and mumbled his name again as you sank down onto his shoulder, rubbing your nose over the small space of skin you could find above his collar. Your fingers dug into his shirt and tried to move the affronting material out of the way because you suddenly felt desperate to find something, anything, even though you trembled all the while, knowing you weren’t going to find anything.

          “Do you want to smell me?” Yoongi whispered, his mouth so close to your ear that his words made you gasp and then groan in frustration even as you nodded against his neck, searching and searching hopelessly.

          “Shit, Yoongi,” you choked on nothing, on nothing but air and the lack of it, the absence of anything but pure, clean, unscented air flowing through your airway that felt toxic and unclean and wrong, wrong, wrong.
